name: Carbohydrate

references.credit: Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Building Blocks Of Nutrition: Carbohydrates
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Dietary Carbohydrates: Sugars and Starches

summary: Carbohydrates are the most common source of energy. This is becuase glucose, the simples form of carbohydrates, is the main energy fuel, not only for our cells, but for the majority of living organisms. Glucose can also be obtained from fats and protein, thus, carbohydrates are not essential for the human organism (the body can also obtain its energy requirements from ketones bodies). Carbohydrates are chains of sugar units. Based on these units, carbohydrates are classified as simple and complex. Carbohydrates are problematic, because their cause high amounts of blood glucose at once (blood glucose spike) which in term cause high amounts of insulin secretion to stabilise the glucose excess. This doesn't happen, though, with dietary fiber (complex carbohydrate), which actually slows down digestion and stabilises glucose levels, but only with simple carbohydrates (sugars). Fiber is the only essential type of carbohydrate. Also, sugars cause inflammation and lead to health problems.
